Yes, package managers would help the development of C++ projects, especially large ones with many dependencies. They could help to relax coding rules, e.g. conservatism regarding the introduction of new dependencies to a project.

In my opinion, a good C++ package manager

* is able to build packages from source (the project only stores configuration files describing how to fetch, configure, build, and install dependencies)
* avoids unnecessary rebuilds of packages (caching and sharing of binaries)
* does not make any assumptions about the underlying build system
* does not make any assumptions about the preferred IDEs of the developers
* is a multi-platform solution
* is itself an open-source project
* allows private-only package repositories, e.g. in an internal network of a company

I'm not familiar with most of the package managers mentioned in thies survey, but most of the above requirements are met by Hunter.

Strongly against language-specific package managers. They pose a security threat, because
1) the code is often updated and not vetted. Thousands of maintainers. Any of them can upload an update at any time, and it's immediately available to the world, without any verification. (This is unlike Linux distros, which pin down releases)
1) the upload and hosting sites are often not secure against hacking, on all levels
2) the download and verification mechanism is often insecure
3) they build on my system, adding more exploit surface
4) I either need to install in my HOME drive (which I positively hate, because it's for data, not executables) or I need to run the package manager as root (bad)

Furthermore, they make a mess, because half the libs are system-wide and the other half is custom-installed, and I never know which one will be used, creating a mess or at least a confusion.
I expect all dependencies to be installable by apt-get. If absolutely necessary, I can add a specific apt repository for e.g. node or perl (1 per language), but it hold up to the same security standards as the Linux distro.

Yes, but I think the lack of a single cross-platform de-facto standard build system hampers this. CMake is filling this gap, but to be honest CMake is garbage. GN seems to be a possible candidate, but isn't supported outside of google-chrome.

Homebrew works great on Mac for installing packages, but it's a system-wide package manager, not a local package manager in the style of npm, and isn't targeted explicitly at developers. Similar efforts exist on Linux (nix for example) but are also system package managers.

What I'd like to see:
- standardized use of a build system via a central repository, so build files can be updated independently of the project
- a package manager that uses the build system to configure and install dependencies

i.e. using "Magical Package Manager"
git clone URL oiio
cd oiio
mpm init  #  downloads build files from central repo, saves to BUILD.gn etc
mpm install  # install or update default dependencies in mpm-packages, builds from source
mpm install additional-dependency # install additional-dependency in mpm-packages, builds from source
mpm configure  # autoconf-style configure
mpm build # runs gn/ninja etc

The idea being your source tree is your own, but build files can be downloaded and updated from the central repo. The central repo also maps a global namespace to other repositories (e.g. oiio maps to github/oiio/oiio), so dependencies can be installed, configured and built with a single command.

- If he is a new user, the barrier of entry is MASSIVE. Not only must he learn a new language, but also the intricacies of linking and compiling dependent libraries into his project

- Projects (especially libraries) must maintain a list of what dependencies are called and how to install them on all OS' package managers, even though the developer does not necessarily use or understand the other OS'.

The best example of package manager I can think of is Rust's Cargo. If a package manager just as good as Cargo existed for C++, I would use it for everything. Think about it:
 - Cargo makes it easy for beginners to learn the language by scaffolding a new project that builds using `cargo init`
 - Cargo has one central searchable and sortable database of libraries located at crates.io. This is unbelievably useful for finding libraries
 - Cargo manages dependencies and their versions, and also locks the all the versions (even transient ones) in the `Cargo.lock` file. This prevents a transient dependency from changing ruining the build for everyone (this has happened MANY times with npm)
 - Cargo does not compile the project, but configures the compiler `rustc` to link and compile libraries with a simple `cargo run`. This is like cmake but without a CMakeLists.txt
 - Cargo makes it easy to publish a library to crates.io, and easy to compile the project, both with a single command

Gentoo, for this purpose, has many tools to generate wrapping packages, so that the system packager is aware of the language-specific packaging. One of the oldest examples of this is, g-cpan, which as the name implies, generates a system package wrapping a given CPAN package (as well as all the packages in the dependency tree as best as possible). It can & does still fail when a given language-specific package relies on a library (usually a C library) or something else that is NOT language-specific, because the language-specific packaging lacks good ways of describing such dependencies in a manner suitable for automated processing.

There is no reasonable testing/integration work going on, as with 'curated' linux distributions and classic library deployment. This leads to the non-existence of different distributions / flavors trading stability against up-to-date features or frozen lines of packages which might have reveived more testing/bugfixing, like enterprise distros or debian. Another aspect is that developers of a project will only consider a single (the 'current') version of dependencies to build their software against, which lowers portability and compatibility efforts and the ability for software to run in legacy or stable/tested software environments. This dependence on the 'latest' software also has severe negative security implications.

For LibreOffice, repeatability, and future proofing, as well as knowing exactly what you get are vital.
My experience of 'magic' package managers is that they repeatedly break, make it practically impossible to re-generate bits from older / historic build configurations - vital for support (repeatability) and licensing questions, and basically are a huge regression. Sure they can put the latest 'foo' and all of its random dependencies into your project. But this is beyond useless if you can't go back in three years and get -exactly- the same bits generated for your package to support it, patch it and re-build it.
Ergo - I hate using, and discourage use of such nonsenses for LibreOffice dependencies. Either we can host (ourselves) and provide snapshots of all of our dependencies at well controlled versions which we have ever shipped - at which point dependencies are "easy" - or we don't bother providing software =)
ie. there is a vast tension between the easy, free-wheeling "busk a load of unknown stuff into my package" approach, and what is needed for maintaining real, quality, repeatable, software for users.
Unless a 'magic' system has a -very- clear means to archive, and a 100% repeatable (and future proof - ie. we need to archive the build tool itself if it is going to ever be backwards incompatible) - and restore from archive pristine dependencies - no matter how 'funky' it is and no matter what features it has, it is worthless to me, (and to most Linux packagers).

A high-quality language-specific package manager is a good thing to have even when using distribution packages, as those are usually easy to maintain and thus up to date in distributions (I've heard there's something excellent in the Haskell area); my general impression with the package managers is that they aren't, though -- thus the "Against" above.

I'm not the main developer, so the answer is no. If it's a personal project, yes, definitely.

What I wanted out of package managers, is that they should also handle the type of compilers used. i.e. if I want to compile the software using mingw64, then I should be able to simply install a mingw64 package. Handling the wide variety of compilers really suck for C++. There has been so many projects that I was unable to compile with mingw or clang, but compiled easily using Microsoft Visual Studio C++.

The compiler itself should suggest what packages are missing, if builds failed.

This was never a problem with PHP, because PHP doesn't differ from environment to environment.

This is even less of a problem with NPM, because everything is centralized around npm.

Currently, all the package managers that I've used except for php, has one weakness, where a package needs to be compiled first. The compilation would usually fail. This is an issue with node-gyp in npm, and in the various pip modules. pip is a big offender in this regards. Even to this day, compiling numpy or scipy is a big PITA and I would have to go download a third party python distro. While I do use it daily, I don't like it at all.
